required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Computer-assisted Screening for Intimate Partner Violence in Family Practice
clinical_study.official_title: Computer-assisted Screening for Intimate Partner Violence in Family Practice - a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study tested the effectiveness of computer-assisted screening for identifying patients at risk of intimate partner violence (IPV) in a Canadian family practice. It was hypothesized that the use of computer-assisted screening among female patients would lead to higher rates of IPV discussion-opportunity and IPV detection during medical consultations, compared to patients receiving standard medical care.

primary_outcome.measure: Discussion-opportunity about risk of partner abuse during physician-patient medical encounter (audiotaped data)
Detection of partner abuse during physician-patient medical encounter (audio taped data)

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient acceptance of the computer-assisted screening(paper-pencil exit survey)

intervention.intervention_name: Interactive computer based health-risk survey before doctor's visit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- woman
- at least 18 years of age
- visiting one of the participant physicians
- in a current or recent intimate relationship during the last 12 months
- having the ability to speak and read English and give consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- visiting a provider other than the regular family physician
- new patient
- previously approached for the study
- very sick
- had a dual appointment (herself and accompanied dependent)

overall_official.affiliation: St. Michael's Hospital and University of Toronto
St. Michael's Hospital and University of Toronto
